title: Where is the plasma membrane found? - Quora

response.answer_text: A plasma membrane(a.k.a. phospholipid bilayer) surrounds all biological cells, eukaryotic cell organelles— e.g., the cell nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, chloroplasts, mitochondria, and more — as well as intracellular transport vesicles. All above links refer to Wikipediaentries.  Phospholipid bilayer image courtesy micro.magnet.fsu.edu(Plasma Membrane)  Nuclear Envelope image courtesy pulpbits.net(Animal Cell Nucleus).  Intracellular transport vesicle image courtesy image.slidesharecdn.com (Vesicle Transport).  Mitochondrion image courtesy s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com (Photosynthesis and Respiration). For much more detail, try search cell membrane (phospholipid bilayer)! See also animated PowerPoint Cell Membranes — Living Walls .ppsx.
